events.description: South Korea reported its largest-ever annual current account surplus of $123.05 billion.

events.event_name: Overseas Foreign Exchange Stabilization Bond Issuance
events.description: The South Korean government issued $3 billion in stabilization bonds, the largest single issuance since 2009.

facts.fact_text: The South Korean won rose to approximately 1,470 per dollar.

evidences.evidence_text: The South Korean won rose to around 1,470 per dollar

facts.fact_text: South Korea's 2025 current account surplus reached US$123.05 billion.
The government issued $3 billion in overseas foreign exchange stabilization bonds in three- and five-year tranches.

evidences.evidence_text: the government successfully issued $3 billion in overseas foreign exchange stabilization bonds, the largest single issuance since 2009. The offering, split into three- and five-year tranches
Strong exports, particularly amid a semiconductor upcycle, further reinforced investor confidence.

claims.claim_text: The bond sale helped ease near-term pressure on the currency.

evidences.evidence_text: the bond sale helped ease near-term pressure on the currency.

claims.claim_text: Tight pricing of the bond offering signaled strong demand.

evidences.evidence_text: The offering... was tightly priced, signaling strong demand and bolstering confidence in South Korea’s external finances.

evidence.evidence_text: The South Korean won rose... supported by signals of net inflows of foreign currency.
Strong exports, particularly amid a semiconductor upcycle, further reinforced investor confidence.
the bond sale helped ease near-term pressure on the currency.
